Description: Copper-gold alloy horse-harness strap-divider: cast, with gold inlay, in the form of a griffin head. There is a circular rivet hole in the back, a smaller rivet hole in the chest, and a pair of elongated slits, one on either side. It has been deliberately given a dark patina in antiquity to enhance the surface contrast with the inlay.
Dimensions: Diameter: 0.20 centimetres (rivet hole at the back)
Diameter: 0.10 centimetres (rivet hole at the front)
Curator's comments: DSR file 6616 (dated 29 June 1995): XRF confirms metal composition to be a deliberate copper-gold alloy. The bronze contains 5-10% tin and traces of less than 1% of lead and silver whereas gold was detected at levels between 2 and 7% on the surface. Both cuprite and metallic gold were present in the black patina. This object was therefore deliberately patinated in antiquity to enhance the colour contrast with the precious metal inlay. Thus the object belongs to a small group of objects sometimes known as Corinthian bronze in the Roman World and as hsmn-km in ancient Egypt.
A very similar griffin-headed "junction box" was offered through auction by Bonhams in London ("Antiquities", 29 April 2004, lot 315, p. 147; cf. also "Antiquities", 28 October 2004, lot 149).
